greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Sum of iterated phi(n).
comment: Iannucci, Moujie and Cohen examine perfect totient numbers: n such that a(n) = n.
link: T. D. Noe, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..10000
C. Defant, On Arithmetic Functions Related to Iterates of the Schemmel Totient Functions, J. Int. Seq. 18 (2015) # 15.2.1

P. Erdos and M. V. Subbarao, On the iterates of some arithmetic functions, The theory of arithmetic functions (Proc. Conf., Western Michigan Univ., Kalamazoo, Mich. 1971), Lecture Notes in Math., 251 , pp. 119-125, Springer, Berlin, 1972. [alternate link]
Douglas E. Iannucci, Deng Moujie and Graeme L. Cohen, On perfect totient numbers, J. Integer Sequences, 6 (2003), #03.4.5.
formula: Erdős & Subbarao prove that a(n) ~ phi(n) for almost all n. In particular, a(n) < n for almost all n. The proportion of numbers up to N for which a(n) > n is at most 1/log log log log N. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Mar 22 2012
example: a(100) = 71 because the iterations of phi (40, 16, 8, 4, 2, 1) sum to 71.
mathematica: nMax=100; a=Table[0, {nMax}]; Do[e=EulerPhi[n]; a[[n]]=e+a[[e]], {n, 2, nMax}]; a (* _T. D. Noe_ *)
Table[Plus @@ FixedPointList[EulerPhi, n] - (n + 1), {n, 72}] (* _Alonso del Arte_, Jan 29 2007 *)
program: a092693 n = (+ 1) $ sum $ takeWhile (/= 1) $ iterate a000010 $ a000010 n
xref: Cf. A003434 (iterations of phi(n) needed to reach 1), A092694 (iterated phi product).
Cf. A082897 and A091847 (perfect totient numbers).
results.author: _T. D. Noe_, Mar 04 2004
